arcName: NDP 2026: The Show Must Go On

questions.title: The Debrief
questions.storyContext: The last firework fades at 8:15pm and the crowd starts pouring out of the stands. Your team is still in the ops room. The dashboards are green for the first time all day. Nobody says anything for a while. You fixed the livestream that was choking at 7:45pm. Before that, you brought the database back from the dead at 4:00pm, just minutes before the gates opened at 4:30pm. Before that, you kept the servers alive through a rehearsal that almost killed them. Before that, you built the whole thing in three weeks. The NDP committee chair walks in. She sits down and says, "I want to know what really happened."
questions.facilitatorPrompt: Before I say anything, I want to hear from everyone. She's asking us directly. Do we tell her about every fire we put out, or do we keep it clean? Think about what happens if she finds out later from someone else.

options.label: Tell her everything. The 2am call, the servers going red during rehearsal, the contractor who wiped the database three hours before gates opened, the livestream choking with millions watching. All of it. She deserves to know, and if it comes out later from someone else, we look worse.

Keep it professional. The report says the app ran successfully with minor technical adjustments during the event. She doesn't need to know about the 4:00pm panic or how close the livestream came to dying. The show worked. That's what matters.

Walk her through the problems, but frame them around what we learned and what we've already started fixing. Not a damage report. A resilience report. She sees the team that got hit four times and kept standing.
Show her the numbers. 99.2% uptime across three hours. 40,000 people served without a crash. The crowd was positive on social media after the fireworks. The data speaks for itself.

questions.title: One Shot
questions.storyContext: A week after NDP, the Minister of Digital Development calls your team in. She says she's read the debrief. She says three crises in three weeks for a national event is not something she wants to explain twice. Then she leans forward: "I can get you one investment. One thing, funded properly, built over five years. Something that makes sure this never happens again. What do you want?" She's serious. But she's also clear that the government will only back one bet.
questions.facilitatorPrompt: She's giving us one shot. I need everyone thinking about this. What was the actual root cause across all four chapters? Was it the infrastructure? The process? The fact that there weren't enough people who knew what to do? If we could only fix one thing, what prevents the most damage?

options.label: A permanent digital command centre for national events. Dedicated servers, dedicated monitoring, a trained team on standby year round. We were scrambling because none of this existed. It should exist.

An AI system that predicts failures before they happen. It watches traffic patterns, scales up automatically when needed, and prepares recovery guides in advance. That contractor wiping the database at 1:30pm? The system flags the suspicious action and reverses it before any damage is done.

A system where no single part can take everything down. Instead of one app that crashes and kills the whole show, fifty smaller pieces that can fail on their own. The livestream problem stays contained instead of spreading.

Train 200 digital officers across every government agency and write step-by-step guides for every type of crisis we faced. Technology breaks. What saved us every time was that someone on this team knew what to do. Scale that.
